[[File:Brooklyn Museum 74.217.3 Drinking Horn.jpg|thumb|Similar drinking horn found at the Brooklyn Museum]] On display in the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], in the African Art and Indian Art of the Americas, is a 19th-century [[drinking horn]]. Originally from the [[Kuba Kingdom]], the drinking horn is made out of wood, iron, and copper alloy. Drinking horns were usually a gift to the friends and family of kings or given to a warrior.
== History ==
=== Kuba Kingdom === {{main|Kuba Kingdom}} [[File:Democratic Republic of Congo.png|thumb|Highlights where Congo is]]
The Kuba Kingdom, founded in the 17th century, is located in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It held nine provinces and chiefdoms were a part of that society.<ref>The Evolution of Culture and Institutions: Evidence from the Kuba Kingdom, http://econ.columbia.edu/files/econ/content/kuba_final.pdf</ref> They were surrounded by other tribes such as the [[Yaka people|Yaka]], Suku, [[Pende people|Pende]], etc. The people from the Kuba kingdom were also known as the Bakuba.<ref>Kuba People, http://www.britannica.com/topic/Kuba-people</ref> They were skilled at hunting, farming, and fishing.<ref>Kuba background, http://kubaafricanart.weebly.com/background.html</ref> One of the more important aspects of the Kuba kingdom was their religion. They were heavily based on the spirits of mother earth and those of their past kings.<ref>Kuba People, http://www.britannica.com/topic/Kuba-people</ref> When it came to their religious ceremonies, the way someone was buried depended on the items placed in the coffin. For the wealthy, they had several items such as delicate figurines, masks, and drinking cups placed in their coffin.<ref>Kuba People, http://www.britannica.com/topic/Kuba-people</ref> The detail and quality of the items told where they were in the social hierarchy.
== 19th Century Drinking Horn ==
=== Object History ===
The Kuba kingdom was located in what is known today as the Democratic Republic of Congo. The kingdom was known for their supernatural powers and spiritual beliefs. Like many kingdoms, royalty was one of the most important parts. Besides having one ruler, they had 19 other rulers underneath the king that managed the 19 groups in Kuba. One of the many ways that these kings showed their status and power was by the amount of money they spent. When it comes to drinking horns, kings would give them out to their family and friends to show their wealth and generosity. Drinking horns were one of the many objects that showed class. The more elegant and intrinsic the design, the higher in society they were.<ref>Bortolot, Alexander. "Kingdoms of the Savanna: The Kuba Kingdom, The Metropolitan Museum of Art."http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/kuba/hd_kuba.htm</ref> The patterns and material made for the drinking horn was an important aspect to show status. Drinking horns were typically used to drink palm wine. The intake of this beverage is an example of something that was done with events held by the king. This may also be an event in which the king shows his generosity and hands out gifts. The drinking horn is in the shape of a buffalo horn that symbolizes the status of the warrior that received it. The design of the horn includes patterns that are in a geometrical shape, a crocodile, and a hand.<ref>Art Institute of Chicago, http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/88689</ref> This specific drinking horn has an attachment made out of iron that can be attached to a belt that the warrior would wear. The fact that the drinking horn has this accessory and option to be attached to a belt shows a high level of status within not only the Kuba society, but also the warrior community.
=== Ownership History ===
This specific drinking horn was first owned by object collector, Raoul Blondiau. He was a collector and diplomat who was based in Brussels. Blondiau is a well-known collector that is mentioned several times in many different institutions.<ref>The Blondiau-Theatre Arts Collection and the Harlem Renaissance, http://metmuseum.org/exhibitions/listings/2012/african-art/blondiau-harlem-renaissance</ref> Blondiau then sold the drinking horn to the [[Theatre Arts Monthly]] in New York City.<ref>Art Institute of Chicago, http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/88689</ref> It was a part of the Harlem Museum of African Art Travelling Exhibit at that time. During the ownership of the Theater Arts Monthly, it was lent to the Chicago Children’s Museum for Negro in Art Week. It was lent during the month of December. Being a part of a traveling exhibit, the object moved around. At one point, it was lent to the Memorial Art Gallery in Rochester, New York. In the Art Institute of Chicago’s website, it is said to have been gifted to the museum by G. F. Harding in 1928. No information has been found concerning G. F. Harding.
== Further reading == Clarke, John Hendrik. "The Old Congo." John Henrik Clarke Virtual Museum. N.p., n.d. Web. <http://www.nbufront.org/MastersMuseums/JHClarke/Contemporaries/LumumbaCongo.html>.
"Kuba - Art & Life in Africa - The University of Iowa Museum of Art." Kuba. University of Iowa Museum of Art, n.d. Web. <https://africa.uima.uiowa.edu/peoples/show/Kuba>
"Kuba Cups - RAND AFRICAN ART." Kuba Cups - RAND AFRICAN ART. N.p., n.d. Web. <http://www.randafricanart.com/Kuba_cup_3.html>.
Lowes, Sara, Nathan Nunn, James A. Robinson, and Jonathan Weigel. "The Evolution of Culture and Institutions: Evidence from the Kuba Kingdom." Autocratic, Democratic, and Optimal Government (n.d.): n. pag. 2 Mar. 2014. Web
Weston, Bonnie E. "Kuba - Rand African Art." Kuba - Rand African Art. N.p., n.d. Web. <http://www.randafricanart.com/kuba_Ngady_aMwaash.html>.

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Cleanup|date=August 2010}} {{infobox winter storm |name=2010 Sahel famine |type=A famine, ending in a heavy rain storm |date formed=3 April<ref name="news24.com"/> |date dissipated=18 September.<ref name="google.com"/> |highest Temperature=49.7 °C (121.3 °F) on 22 June, in [[Dongola]], Sudan<ref name="MastersNOAA"/> |total fatalities=9 confirmed, 42 indirectly, 20 unconfirmed |areas affected=[[Sahel]] |}} [[File:Sahel Map-Africa rough.png|thumb|right|250px|The Sahel forms a belt up to 1000 km wide, spanning Africa from the Atlantic Ocean to the [[Red Sea]].]] [[File:Senegalrivermap.png|right|thumb|250px|A map of the [[Sénégal River drainage basin]].]] [[File:Senegal dry wet 540.jpg|thumb|250px|The vegetation in the Sahel follows seasonal rainfall. In March, during the [[dry season]], rainfall and lush vegetation don’t extend north of the [[Gulf of Guinea]]. September brings rain and vegetation into the Sahel as far north as the northern edge of [[Lake Chad]]. Photographs from [[Senegal]] show the difference in vegetation between the dry (left) and wet (right) seasons.]]
<!--Per MOS:BOLDTITLE and WP:SBE, please do not reword this to include the article's title.-->A large-scale, drought-induced [[famine]] occurred in Africa's [[Sahel]] region and many parts of the neighboring [[Sénégal River Area]] from February to August 2010. It is one of many famines to have hit the region in recent times.<ref>[http://www.worldpress.org/Africa/719.cfm Famine Drought Spreads Across Continent] Worldpress.org</ref>
The [[Sahel]] is the ecoclimatic and [[biogeographic]] zone of transition between the [[Sahara desert]] in the north of Africa and the [[Sudanian savannas]] in the south, covering an area of 3,053,200 square kilometers. It is a transitional [[ecoregion]] of semi-arid grasslands, [[savanna]]s, [[steppes]], and thorn shrublands.<ref name="wwf"> {{WWF ecoregion | name = Sahelian Acacia savanna | id=at0713 | accessdate =7 December 2009 }}</ref>
The neighboring [[Sénégal River Area]] contains various vegetation types and covers parts or all of [[Mauritania]], [[Mali]], [[Senegal]] and [[Guinea]]. It has also had very low rainfall over the last year according to the [[UN]], NGOs and the [[Organisation pour la mise en valeur du fleuve Sénégal|Senegal River Basin Development Authority]].<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/222031/127409150030.htm ACT Alert: Food Insecurity in Mauritania due to Drought situation in the Sahel region] Reuters AlertNet</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/222031/127549655260.htm ACT Preliminary Appeal: Food insecurity in Mauritania due to Drought in the Sahel region] AlertNet</ref> Sudan set a new temperature record of 49.7 °C (121.3 °F) on 22 June, in the town of [[Dongola]].<ref name="MastersNOAA">{{cite web|last=Masters |first=Jeff |title=NOAA: June 2010 the globe's 4th consecutive warmest month on record |url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1544 |work=Weather Underground |publisher=Jeff Masters' WunderBlog |accessdate=21 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719104107/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1544 |archivedate=19 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Overview== Famine and food shortages were present in the following Sahelian countries during 2010 after heavy rains hit the region in late 2009, followed by a [[heat wave]]:<ref name="alertnet.org">[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE60Q14F.htm "Strong risk" of 2010 famine in Africa's Sahel – EU] Reuters AlertNet</ref> [[Sudan]], the [[Niger]], northern [[Nigeria]], northern [[Cameroon]], [[Chad]], [[Senegal]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Mauritania]], [[Mali]], as well as in parts of the neighboring [[Sénégal River Area]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="magharebia.com">[http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/features/awi/newsbriefs/general/2010/05/18/newsbrief-05 Mauritania heat wave kills 7] Magharebia</ref>
In December 2009, both [[USAID]] and several NGOs predicted an increased food insecurity situation in more of the southern [[Cercles of Mali|districts]] of Mali as compared to the same time the previous year.<ref>[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:9MecWs-5JVIJ:pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNADS238.pdf+2010tiboktou+famin&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESibJ501V8unNlpZyLydMWdvnISPQtmOwyqvliUjPXDFJsc3eWrgAg6y876gyLbbktdGqoIFJax3G9c6J7TM3mhvK558us4wZm0cBkx2ynmHsYGFPuo3SN-jNkm4EQIHZP4W5kAN&sig=AHIEtbTuGBncT_7sqQAfP5DCui2xIUYTEg Mali Food Security Outlook] PNADS238.pdf – Powered by Google Docs</ref>
==Possible causes== [[File:Sahel rainfall timeseries en.svg|thumb|250px|More than a century of rainfall data in the Sahel show an unusually wet period from 1950 until 1970 (positive index values), followed by extremely dry years from 1970 to 1990 (negative index values). From 1990 until present rainfall returned to levels slightly below the 1898–1993 average, but year-to-year variability remains high.]]
[[File:Seasonal westafrica rainfall mean 20070501 20070930.gif|thumb|250px|Map showing mean rainfall amount (mm) for the monsoon season (1 May – 30 September) in West Africa. Period 1995–2006. Based on NOAA/CPC Climatology Method Rainfall Estimates. Africa Rainfall Climatology (CPC ARC) Series.]]
[[File:Greening Sahel 1982-1999.jpg|thumb|250px|Recent "Greening" of the Sahel: The results of trend analysis of time series over the Sahel region of seasonally integrated NDVI using NOAA AVHRR NDVI-data from 1982 to 1999.]]
===Environmental problems=== The Western donor nations once theorised that the drought in the [[Sahel]] primarily was caused by humans over-using [[natural resources]] in the region through [[overgrazing]], [[deforestation]]<ref>{{cite journal | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0143622803000183| doi=10.1016/j.apgeog.2003.08.004 | volume=23 | issue=4 | title=Deforestation in afforestation priority zone in Sudano-Sahelian Nigeria | journal=Applied Geography | pages=227–259| year=2003 | last1=Odihi | first1=J }}</ref> and poor [[land management]].<ref>[http://www.eden-foundation.org/project/desertif.html "Desertification – a threat to the Sahel", August 1994]</ref><ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0801/p01s02-woaf.html Hunger is spreading in Africa]</ref> In the late 1990s, climate model studies suggested that large-scale climate changes were also triggers for the drought.
In the early 2000s, after the phenomenon of [[global dimming]] was discovered, some speculatively suggested, that the drought was likely caused by air pollution generated in [[Eurasia]] and North America. The pollution changed the properties of clouds over the Atlantic Ocean, disturbing the [[monsoon]]s and shifting the [[tropical rain belt|tropical rain]]s southwards. [[Global dimming]], the blocking of sunlight by man-made [[particulate]]s, has been identified as one culprit for a decades-long drought across [[sub-Saharan Africa]].<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/transcripts/3310_sun.html Transcript of the program "Dimming the Sun"] from [[NOVA (TV series)|NOVA]], [[Public Broadcasting Service]] airdate: 18 April 2006</ref>
A 2006 study by [[NOAA]] scientists [[Rong Zhang]] and [[Thomas L. Delworth]] suggests that the [[Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation]]/(MAO) plays a leading role. An AMO warm phase strengthens the summer rainfall over [[Sahel]], while a cold phase reduces it.<ref name="Zhang2006">{{cite journal |last=Zhang |first=Rong |author2=Delworth, Thomas L. |year=2006 |title=Impact of Atlantic multidecadal oscillations on India/Sahel rainfall and Atlantic hurricanes |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=33 |issue=17 |pages=L17712 |doi=10.1029/2006GL026267 |url= |quote= |bibcode=2006GeoRL..3317712Z}}</ref> The AMO entered a warm phase in 1995 and, by assuming the presence of a theoretical 70-year cycle (following peaks in ≈1880 and ≈1950), it would probably peak around about 2020.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Enfield |first=David B. |author2=Cid-Serrano, Luis |year=2009 |title=Secular and multi-decadal warming in the North Atlantic and their relationships with major hurricane activity |journal=International Journal of Climatology |volume=30 |pages= n/a|doi=10.1002/joc.1881 |url= |quote= }}</ref>
The Sahel's farmers have been largely cleared of blame for the 19th century's Sahel droughts.<ref name="scidev.net">{{cite web|author=Katie Mantell |url=http://www.scidev.net/en/news/farmers-freed-of-blame-for-sahel-drought.html |title=Farmers freed of blame for Sahel drought |publisher=SciDev.Net |date=10 October 2003 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The Sahel region's rains in the 1930s and 2040s were caused by the recent warming of the Indian Ocean, rather than by over-farming causing environmental degradation as previously assumed, according to a new joint [[Scidev]]/UN study.<ref name="scidev.net"/> With both a 3.5 C. rise in the Niger's temperature over the last decade and with [[irrigation|irrigated]] land accounting for only 0.1% of the Niger's inhabitable land, regular [[famine]] crisis is inevitable in most years. Acute water shortages, which are common in the region's harsh weather, make irrigation systems all the more important for the local farmers.<ref>"[http://www.mdsomerfield.com/?p=47 What caused the 2010 Niger famine?]". {{dead link|date=December 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Dionysus</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">-://climate-change.suite101.com/article.cfm/what-caused-the-niger-famine-in-2010</ref><ref name="youtube.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXrwYLxPnjs&feature=related |title=Anthem Mali |publisher=YouTube |date=15 February 2008 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
===The Demise of Lake Chad=== The [[Lake Chad basin]] straddles the borders of both [[Niger]], Nigeria, [[Cameroon]] and [[Chad]]. The lake is situated {{convert|281|m|ft}} above sea level and is diminishing over time due to lack of rain water and major rivers running into it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/News/cha006_drought_env.htm |title=cha006 Drought in Chad bodes ill for food supply |publisher=Afrol.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> According to the UN the marshy lake shrank as much as by 95% from about 1963 to 1998<ref name="United Nations 2007">[http://na.unep.net/atlas/webatlas.php?id=58 Atlas of Our Changing Environment]</ref> yet they also state that "The 2007 (satellite) image shows significant improvement over previous years". Lake Chad is economically important, providing water to more than 20 million people living in the four countries that surround it ([[Chad]], Cameroon, [[Niger]], and [[Nigeria]]) on the edge of the [[Sahara Desert]]. The plant [[Typha Australis]] (or the big cattail) is cutting off water supplies in the [[Chad Basin|Lake Chad Basin]], and has slashed available water supplies in the Chad's region.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="mdsomerfield.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.mdsomerfield.com/?p=47 |title= What caused the 2010 Niger famine? |website= MD Somerfield: A minimum viable blog |accessdate=24 August 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The only protected area is [[Lake Chad Game Reserve]], which covers half of the area next to the lake that belongs to Nigeria. The whole lake has been declared a [[Ramsar site]] of international importance.
Lake Chad's role in the Sahel famine has attracted attention partly due to the [[desertification]] that is increasingly claiming a huge swath not just of the Sahel region but also the entire African continent. According to a [[United Nations]] environment program, in 2002, this phenomenon, which is a process where the soil loses the capacity to retain necessary moisture, has covered nearly half of Africa.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Famine: A Short History|last=Grada|first=Cormac|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=2009|isbn=9780691122373|location=Princeton|pages=271}}</ref> It was revealed that the Sahel region is one of the areas that are worst affected.
The problem is also highlighted by the discovery of fossil pollens indicating that, in ancient times, the shores of Lake Chad supported a well-watered [[savanna]], which contributed to a lesser level of [[arid]]ity in the Sahel area.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Floods, Famines, and Emperors: El Nino and the Fate of Civilizations|last=Fagan|first=Brian|publisher=Perseus Books Group|year=2009|isbn=9780786727681|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> It was found that around 3,000 B.C., the Sahel averaged 650 millimeters of rainfall a year compared to an average of 350 millimeters recorded today.<ref name=":0" /> Given the issue of desertification, even if Lake Chad was not directly a cause of the famine, its potential demise is expected to further aggravate the problem. There are studies that show that the incidence of famine is reportedly related to the delicate seasonal variations in the [[Intertropical convergence zone|intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ)]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Tales of the Earth: Paroxysms and Perturbations of the Blue Planet|last=Officer|first=Charles|last2=Page|first2=Jake|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1994|isbn=9780195090482|location=Oxford|pages=104}}</ref>
The shrinking of Lake Chad is blamed on the long droughts as well as the uptick in human activities such as the use of the lake's water for irrigation,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Deserts|last=Claybourne|first=Anna|publisher=Hodder Wayland|year=2005|isbn=1583404252|location=Suffolk|pages=19}}</ref> the destruction of wooded areas for firewood, and the shift from the cultivation of corn and wheat to rice as the staple crop.<ref name=":1" />
====The Ubangi River diversion proposal==== In the 1960s, a plan was proposed to divert the [[Ubangi River]] into [[Lake Chad]]. The copious amount of water from the Ubangi would revitalize the dying Lake Chad and provide livelihood in fishing and enhanced agriculture to tens of millions of central Africans and [[Sahel]]ians. Inter-basin water transfer schemes were proposed in the 1980s and 1990s by [[Nigeria]]n engineer [[J. Umolu]] (ZCN Scheme) and Italian firm [[Bonifica]] (Transaqua Scheme).<ref>[http://hydroweb.com/jeh/jeh1999/bunu.pdf Journal of Environmental Hydrology, Vol. 7, 1999]</ref><ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=mg12917615.500 New Scientist, 23 March 1991 Africa at a [[drainage divide|Watershed]] (Ubangi – Lake Chad Inter-basin transfer)]</ref><ref>Umolu, J. C.; 1990, Macro Perspectives for Nigeria’s Water Resources Planning, Proc. of the First Biennial National Hydrology Symposium, Maiduguri, Nigeria, pp. 218–262 (discussion of Ubangi-Lake Chad diversion schemes)</ref><ref>The Changing Geography of Africa and the Middle East By Graham Chapman, Kathleen M. Baker, University of London School of Oriental and African Studies, 1992 Routledge</ref><ref>[http://dwb.unl.edu/Teacher/NSF/C09/C09Links/www.ccnet.com/~mcumolu/globclim.html Combating Climate Induced Water And Energy Deficiencies In West Central Africa (Ubangi – Lake Chad Inter-basin transfer)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526135224/http://dwb.unl.edu/Teacher/NSF/C09/C09Links/www.ccnet.com/~mcumolu/globclim.html |date=26 May 2011 }}</ref> In 1994, the Lake Chad Basin Commission (LCBC) proposed a similar project and at a March 2008 Summit, the Heads of State of the LCBC member countries committed to the diversion project.<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-03-28-voa33.cfm Voice of America News, 28 March 2008 African Leaders Team Up to Rescue Lake Chad] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509154953/http://www.voanews.com/english/2008-03-28-voa33.cfm |date=9 May 2008 }}</ref> In April 2008, the LCBC advertised a request for proposals for a World Bank-funded feasibility study.
===The possible effects of cash crops=== Cotton and [[Bambara groundnut|groundnut]]s are two of Chad's four major [[cash crop]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mongabay.com/reference/country_studies/chad/ECONOMY.html |title=Chad – Economy |publisher=Mongabay.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Mali's major cash crops are peanuts<ref name="infoplease.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/world/A0859452.html#axzz0wmLMpnS8 |title=24 X 7 |publisher=Infoplease.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> and cotton.<ref name="infoplease.com"/><ref name="fairtrade.org.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.fairtrade.org.uk/producers/cotton/dougourakoroni_cotton_producers.aspx |title=The Fairtrade Foundation | Fairtrade – Dougourakoroni Cotton Producers Co-operative, Mali |publisher=Fairtrade |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="highbeam.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-146711515.html |title=AFRICAN COTTON PRODUCERS' APPEAL.(rules for cotton trade)(Brief article) – Europe Agri | HighBeam Research – FREE trial |publisher=Highbeam.com |date=19 May 2006 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/360071/Mali/54981/Economy |title=Mali :: Economy – Britannica Online Encyclopedia |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="museumstuff.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.museumstuff.com/learn/topics/Mali::sub::Economy |title=Mali : Economy |publisher=Museumstuff.com |date=28 July 2005 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="africanexecutive.com">{{cite web|author=The African Executive |url=http://www.africanexecutive.com/modules/magazine/articles.php?article=403 |title=History of Mali |publisher=The African Executive |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="sciencedirect.com">{{citation|doi=10.1016/0305-750X(87)90129-X|title=Manufactured goods supply and cash crops in sub-Saharan Africa|journal=World Development|volume=15|issue=10–11|pages=1353|year=1987|last1=Berthelemy|first1=J.C|last2=Morrisson|first2=C}}</ref> [[Mali]]'s cotton production has grown from 500,000 tonnes in 1997 to a record 635,000 tonnes in 2003, which has pleased the [[African Association of Cotton Producers]], but has also led to a claim that [[cash crops]] are being put before food and fodder crops in [[Mali]], Burkina Faso and [[Chad]].<ref name="infoplease.com"/><ref name="fairtrade.org.uk"/><ref name="highbeam.com"/><ref name="britannica.com"/> <ref name="britannica.com"/><ref name="museumstuff.com"/><ref name="africanexecutive.com"/><ref name="sciencedirect.com"/> [[Cassava]] production has fallen slightly in [[Burkina Faso]] since 2007, relative to cotton output. Their cash crops are cotton, [[Bambara groundnut|groundnuts]], [[shea nut]]s, and [[sesame]].<ref>[http://www.theodora.com/wfbcurrent/burkina_faso/burkina_faso_economy.html Burkina Faso Economy 2010]</ref><ref>[http://www.mbendi.com/land/af/bf/p0005.htm Burkina Faso – An Overview]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2834.htm |title=Burkina Faso |publisher=State.gov |date=8 September 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110209154615/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2834.htm| archivedate= 9 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtravelguide.net/country/45/business/Africa/Burkina-Faso.html |title=Business etiquette in Burkina Faso |publisher=Worldtravelguide.net |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The Sahel's farmers are largely cleared of blame for the 20th century's Sahel droughts<ref name="scidev.net"/> and this is supported by the position that several of the cash crops in the Sahel region have desirable ecological effects such as the tree crops and the [[legume]]s, which help prevent the process of desertification.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The IUCN Sahel Studies 1989|last=International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources|first=|publisher=IUCN|year=1989|isbn=2880329779|location=Gland, Switzerland|pages=122}}</ref> However, there is the enduring question of whether cash crops like cotton are more important than food plants like wheat and [[casava]]. This issue persists as studies cite that the famine is linked to the direct entitlement failure that affected people's access to food.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Introducing Money|last=Peacock|first=Mark|publisher=Routledge|year=2013|isbn=9780415539869|location=Oxon|pages=}}</ref>
===Over-population=== Many of the world's countries, including many in Sub-saharan Africa, the Middle East and [[South East Asia]], have seen a sharp rise in population since the end of the [[Cold War]]. The fear is that high population numbers are putting further strain on natural resources, food supplies, fuel supplies, employment, housing, etc.; in some of the less fortunate countries. The population of [[Chad]] has, for example, ultimately grown from 6,279,921 in 1993 to 10,329,208 in 2009,<ref name=cia>{{cite web|author=Central Intelligence Agency |authorlink=Central Intelligence Agency |publisher=[[The World Factbook]] |title=Chad |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cd.html |year=2009 |accessdate=28 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129154104/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cd.html |archivedate=29 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> further straining its resources. [[Nigeria]] is witnessing a similar growth in population, strained resources and a possible [[Human overpopulation|over-population]] problem in the near future.
The situation was most acute in northern, western and central Africa. Refugees from places like the [[Sudan]] have helped further strain the resources of neighboring states like the Chad and Egypt. The nation is also host to roughly 255,000 [[refugee]]s from Sudan's [[Darfur]] region, and about 77,000 refugees from the [[Central African Republic]], whilst approximately 188,000 Chadians have been displaced by their own civil war and famines, have either fled to either the Sudan, the Niger or, more recently, [[Libya]].<ref name="http">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2010/jun/03/drought-hunger-west-Africa |title=Severe drought causes hunger for 10 million in west Africa |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607034159/http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2010/jun/03/drought-hunger-west-africa |archivedate=2010-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wfp.org/countries/chad |title=Chad | WFP | United Nations World Food Programme – Fighting Hunger Worldwide |publisher=WFP |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wfp.org/content/emergency-food-assistance-drought-affected-population-chad |title=Emergency Food Assistance to Drought-affected Population in Chad | WFP | United Nations World Food Programme – Fighting Hunger Worldwide |publisher=WFP |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>

===Aid workers being driven off by kidnappers=== On 25 August a French aid worker was kidnapped in Chad.<ref name="afrikaspeaks.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.afrikaspeaks.com/?p=Archive&cat=General&title=French+aid+worker+seized+in+Chad&curpage=61 |title=French aid worker seized in Chad " Afrika Speaks | Reporting News in Africa by Africans. General News, Entertainment News, Sports News, Business News, Health and Environmental News in Africa |publisher=Afrikaspeaks.com |date=10 January 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The kidnapping of foreigners along the Chad/Darfur border became more frequent in 2009. A French NGO worker was taken and then murdered on 29 October 2009,<ref name="sudaneseonline.com">{{cite web|author=ELAINE GANLEY – 6 hours ago |url=http://www.sudaneseonline.com/en2/publish/Latest_News_1/French_aid_worker_killed_in_Chad.shtml |title=French aid worker killed in Chad |publisher=Sudaneseonline.com |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> and an unidentified Red Cross worker was captured on 10 November 2009.<ref name="earthtimes.org">{{cite web|author=Earth Times Staff |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/news/294073,red-cross-worker-kidnapped-in-chad.html |title=Red Cross worker kidnapped in Chad | Earth Times News |publisher=Earthtimes.org |date=10 November 2009 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Many NGOs and charities have begun to restrict the areas covered by their aid work in Niger, Chad, and Sudan due to the ever-present risk of [[bandit]]s and [[kidnapp]]ers. The organizations are thus pulling out in fear of their workers' lives.
Most [[international aid agencies]] have been withdrawing workers from some areas of the Sahel, due to the regional kidnapping crisis. [[Niger]]'s government spokesman [[Mahamane Lawali Danda]] told the [[BBC|B.B.C.]] that the pullout was a surprise to him since no one had told him or his government that Niger was on the list of dangerous 'kidnapper infested' [[pariah nations]], along with [[Chad]], [[Darfur]] and [[Sudan]]. Strangely, [[Mauritania]] and [[Mali]] were not on the list of dangerous nations, despite several [[al-Qaeda]] lead kidnappings in both during 2009.<ref name="npr.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129316900 |title=In Grip Of Drought, Floods, Niger Faces Hunger Crisis |publisher=NPR |date=20 August 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110215011701/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129316900| archivedate= 15 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

==List of events== {{weather|portal}}
===January=== 11 January saw an emerging famine situation in south eastern [[Sudan]] according to the UN, NGOs, the EU and various Charities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_January2010_Alert_final.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094239/http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_January2010_Alert_final.pdf |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
The government of [[Niger]] says 7,800,000 risk starvation in 2010 as heavy drought and high heat hit Niger, [[Burkina Faso]], Mali, [[Chad]] and northern [[Nigeria]] on both 27 and 28 January and was estimated to need about $220,000,000 million this year in food and agricultural aid.<ref name="alertnet.org"/> The EU's [[ECHO (European Commission)|ECHO aid department]] said of signs of food shortages were in Niger and spreading to neighbors such as [[Burkina Faso]], Mali, [[Chad]] and northern [[Nigeria]] as 15,000,000 are estimated to face a chronic food shortage in Niger. The EU and UN also put out a famine alert for Niger, [[Burkina Faso]], Mali, [[Chad]] and northern [[Nigeria]] and began to appeal for aid<ref name="alertnet.org"/> on the 28th. The EU, China and [[Russia]] stopped giving Niger aid in 2009 after President [[Mamadou Tandja]] defied UN, EU and worldwide criticism over extending his term in office.<ref name="alertnet.org"/>
===February=== The UN, NGOs and charities warned of heavy [[food insecurity]] in [[Southern Sudan]] throughout February due to an emerging famine and the ongoing conflict between [[Misseriya]] [[nomad]] in the [[Southern Kordofan]] department. The rainfall was reported at an all-time low in [[Mauritania]] and neighboring parts of [[Senegal]] during most of February and early March.
The EU warns of a pending Sahel famine centered upon Niger, Burkina Faso and Chad<ref>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/177702.php West Africa's Sahel Belt Could Face Famine In 2010]</ref> on 1 February.
===March=== [[Human Rights Watch]] said that [[Al Qaeda]] should stop targeting African civilians and aid workers on 16 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2010/03/16/african-al-qaeda-should-stop-targeting-civilians |title=African Al Qaeda Should Stop Targeting Civilians | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=16 March 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110212001740/http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2010/03/16/african-al-qaeda-should-stop-targeting-civilians| archivedate= 12 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
A drought was confirmed to have hit parts of [[Burkina Faso]] on 10 March, by [[USAID]] and the UN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/dbc.nsf/doc104?OpenForm&rc=1&cc=bfa |title=ReliefWeb " Burkina Faso |publisher=.reliefweb.int |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 13 March 2010 the UN, NGOs, the EU and various charities put out a famine alert for parts of southern [[Sudan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_March_2010_Alert_final.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094323/http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_March_2010_Alert_final.pdf |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On 15 March 2010 Britain's [[Save The Children]] charity launched an appeal as 840,000 Nigerians are confirmed to be in imminent risk of a famine.<ref name="soschildrensvillages.org.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.soschildrensvillages.org.uk/charity-news/archive/2010/03/niger-famine-2010-emergency-appeal |title=Niger Famine 2010 Emergency Appeal – SOS Children |publisher=Soschildrensvillages.org.uk |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 17 March 2010, a famine was declared in [[Mao (Chad)|Mao]] in Chad's sand-swept [[Kanem region]].<ref name="wfp.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.wfp.org/content/theres-famine-chad |title=There's A Famine In Chad | WFP | United Nations World Food Programme – Fighting Hunger Worldwide |publisher=WFP |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 23 March 2010, major [[Dust storm|sandstorm]]s hit Mauritania, Senegal, the [[Gambia]], [[Guinea Bissau]], Guinea and inland [[Sierra Leone]]. Another hit southern [[Algeria]], inland [[Mauritania]], Mali and northern [[Côte d’Ivoire]]<ref>[http://www.eosnap.com/?tag=sand-storm Eosnap.com]</ref> at the same time.
===April=== During April and June, [[Islamic Relief]] (IR) sent aid workers to the [[North Kordofan]] to help improve their 16-year-old [[Um Dam]] and [[North Kordofan Water Project]] (NKWP).<ref name="islamic-relief.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.islamic-relief.com/wherewework/9-SD-sudan.aspx |title=Sudan | Islamic Relief Worldwide |publisher=Islamic-relief.com |date=24 October 2009 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The UN, NGOs, charities and the Sudanese government reported that food security was a major concern in South Sudan and would stay at risk until the rainy season in September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_Outlook_April_2010_final.PDF |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094337/http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_Outlook_April_2010_final.PDF |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
By 8 April 2010, [[starvation|starving]] children and elders filled the wards of a hospital in [[Akobo, Sudan|Akobo]], Sudan.<ref name="news24.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/UN-Sudan-famine-worsening-20100408 |title=UN: Sudan famine worsening: News24: Africa: News |publisher=News24 |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Several aid groups like [[Save the Children]] and [[Medair]] found out that 46% of children in the region were malnourished.<ref name="news24.com"/> The U.N. blamed two years of failed rainfall<ref name="news24.com"/><ref name="news24.com"/> and the ongoing [[tribe|tribal]] clashes in the region for helping to create the [[humanitarian crisis]] in southern Sudan.<ref name="news24.com"/> The [[World Food Programme]](WFP) was feeding 80,000 (up from 20,000 since April 2009) and the U.N. says 4,300,000 people in southern Sudan need food aid.<ref name="news24.com"/>
On 23 April 2010, said [[Niger]]ien [[Culture Minister]] [[Aminata Takoubakoyea]], there was a reported food supply deficit of 119,700 tonnes and a fodder supply deficit of 16,000,000 tonnes. Niger's leading musicians and singers held a charity concert in [[Niamey]] to assist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriqueavenir.org/en/2010/04/23/nigerien-artists-initiate-concerts-to-assist-famine-victims/ |title=Nigerien artists initiate concerts to assist famine victims |publisher=Afriqueavenir.org |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
===May=== On 1 May 2010, the West African nation of Chad was on the verge of a nationwide famine as drought, armed conflict, and an influx of [[Darfur]] refugees all contributed to a chronic [[Economic shortage|food shortage]] that now affects 2,000,000 people (20% of the country's total population). Various aid groups, NGOs and charities said a catastrophic famine could hit the country in the near future if food relief does not arrive soon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/05/2010519416873543.html |title=Chad 'on the brink' of famine – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 May 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110309065616/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/05/2010519416873543.html| archivedate= 9 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The UN warned that a famine had hit the town of [[Mao (Chad)|Mao]] in Chad's [[Kanem Region|Kanem]] region.<ref name="wfp.org"/>
The city of [[Niamey]], Niger took in refugees from [[Tillabéri department]] 12 days before, after they turned up hoping the city would help them. By 3 May 2010, the towns of [[Kongomé]], [[Zinder]], [[Tanout]] and [[Dalli, Tanout|Dalli]] were the worst hit by the drought.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/04/world/africa/04niger.html | work=The New York Times | title=Famine Persists in Niger, but Denial Is Past | first=Adam | last=Nossiter | date=3 May 2010| accessdate=24 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
[[Morocco]] gives a short term cash loan to both the [[Niger]] and [[Mali]].<ref name="guardian1"/>
NGOs and Charities report famine conditions [[Kindal]] region on the 5th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.temoust.org/famine-and-drought-in-the-kidal,14560 |title=FAMINE AND DROUGHT IN THE KIDAL REGION, NORTHERN MALI – Temoust.org | Le portail du peuple touareg berbère Kel Tamasheq |publisher=Temoust.org |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 12 and 26 May 2010, both [[Mauritania]], the [[Sénégal River drainage basin|Sénégal River Area]] and neighboring parts of both [[Senegal]] and [[Mali]] faced both drought and famine.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/>
On 14 May 2010, [[USAID]] issued a food shortage alert for the [[Kordofan]] states.<ref name="guardian1"/>
Seven died of dehydration in [[Ghaidi Magha]], Mauritania, near the [[Mali]]an border on 18 May 2010.<ref name="magharebia.com"/>
[[Afrol News]] reported on 25 May that about 2,000,000 Chadians were at risk of having a famine occur in their regions after the combined effects of 2 years of drought and pestilence had ruined their harvest yet again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/36193 |title=afrol News – Chad could slip into famine |publisher=Afrol.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 27 and 28 May 2010, Mali and Niger faced a famine situation in their northern territories. The [[Kidal]], [[Timboktu]] and [[Gao]] had their crops and livestock die off. [[Gao market|Gao’s historic nomad market]] had virtually no food stuffs or animal fodder in it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tomathon.com/mphp/2010/05/niger-mali-hunger-famine-or-both/ |title=Niger, Mali: Hunger, famine or both | The Tomathon |publisher=Tomathon.com |date=27 May 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
31 May saw [[Chad]] embroiled in a fiscal controversy. A 12-metre statue of a horseman, the Rond-point de la Grande Armée, in the capital [[N'djamena]], cost over $3,000,000. Both local critics, NGOs and overseas [[Donation|donor]] nations all wondered where the money had come from and thought it would have been better spent on buying food and irrigation equipment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0531/1224271503594.html |title=Spectre of famine haunts Chad as funds diverted to strengthen army – The Irish Times – Mon, May 31, 2010 |work=The Irish Times |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
===June=== NGOs, various charities and the UN warned of heavy food shortages and [[food insecurity]] in Sudan's [[Blue Nile]], [[Kassala]], [[Janub Darfur]], [[South Kordofan]] and [[North Kordofan]] departments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_FSOU_June_2010_final.PDF |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094408/http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/Sudan_FSOU_June_2010_final.PDF |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fews.net/docs/Publications/EAST_Outlook_May_2010_final.PDF |title=Microsoft Word – EAST_Outlook_May_2010_final |format=PDF |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Dehydration]] was reported to have killed one person in Niger, while others in the region were at risk of water shortages on 1 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/world/africa/drought+threatens+african+humanitarian+crisis/3697427 |title=Drought threatens African humanitarian crisis – Channel 4 News |publisher=Channel4.com |date=1 July 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704064140/http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/world/africa/drought%2Bthreatens%2Bafrican%2Bhumanitarian%2Bcrisis/3697427 |archivedate=4 July 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Severe drought caused to 10,000,000 to go seriously short on as the Eastern Sahel crisis increases and local food prices surge on 3 June.<ref name="http"/> Niger has 7,100,00 victims, Chad has 2,000,000 victims and other country have 900,000 victims in total. [[Niger]], Chad, the eastern parts of [[Mali]] and northern [[Cameroon]] have also been badly affected by the failed rains and scorching heat, according to the UN [[World Food Programme]].<ref name="http"/> The WFP, which plans to assist 3,600,000 people in the coming months and said the crisis is expected to last at least until the next harvest in September 2010.<ref name="http"/> The British charity [[Save the Children]], launched an emergency appeal for Niger. Starving families were reported as either have travelled more than 600 miles to reach the capital Niamey to find work and/or beg for food, while others have crossed the border in [[Nigeria]].<ref name="http"/> A Similar situation is occurring in Chad as, desperate Chadians fled into southern [[Libya]]. [[Sudan]] and [[Burkina Faso]] were in a server food insecure situation too.<ref name="http"/>
On 6 June 2010, growing famine in the [[Niger]] drove thousand of [[refugee]]s into the [[Nigeria]]n provinces of [[Kano]] and [[Katsina]] states. About 7,000,000 were facing a food shortage crisis in Niger.<ref>{{cite web|author=6 June 2010 by Hussaini Umar |url=http://africabusiness.com/2010/06/06/famine-nigeriens-in-flocks-troop-into-nigeria-%E2%80%93-engaged-in-water-selling-business/ |title=Famine: Nigeriens in flocks, troop into Nigeria – engaged in water selling business |publisher=AfricaBusiness.com |date=6 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 7 June the Malian Government's Early [[Warning System]] released an estimate that 258,000 people were suffering from [[malnutrition]] in the towns of [[Gao]] and [[Kidal]] in April. Low and erratic rainfall in 2009 had occurred in [[Timbuktu]], [[Kidal]], and [[Gao]], leading to a heavy regional drought.<ref name="fromthefield">{{cite web|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/222031/127608650261.htm |title=News |publisher=AlertNet |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Hundreds of refugees moved to [[Gao]] from [[Burkina Faso]] and [[Niger]], but were now too weak with starvation to leave [[Mali]]. The UN and Mali's government asked the [[developed nations]] for food aid and financial help in the face of the growing humanitarian crisis.<ref name="fromthefield" /> The amount taken in Nigeria's harvest was down by 65,000 tonnes, whilst Niger had virtually nothing to take from their [[harvest]].
On 8 June 2010, France food aid to and the [[European Union]] pledged an additional $28,000,000 million to help the millions of victims in the [[Niger]], the [[Chad]], Burkina Faso, and northern [[Nigeria]].<ref name="voanews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/EU-Boosting-Food-Aid-for-Niger-95860634.html |title=EU Boosting Food Aid for Niger | Africa | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=8 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The charity [[Save the Children]] sent a team to [[Aguie]] in Niger, 850 km north east from the capitol [[Niamey]], to set up an aid centre on the 8th<ref name="news.sky.com">{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Niger-Drought-Thousands-Of-Children-Face-Starvation-Unless-Help-Arrives-Save-The-Children-Says/Article/201006215645969?f=rss |title=Niger Drought: Thousands Of Children Face Starvation Unless Help Arrives, Save The Children Says | Home | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> and reported back on the 9th than 350,000 children faced severe malnutrition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigpondnews.com/articles/World/2010/06/09/Millions_starved_from_Niger_drought_471730.html |title=Millions starved from Niger drought | World |publisher=BigPond News |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> On 9 June, various groups of [[hydrologists]], geologists and scientists in the Sahara desert used magnetic [[imaging technology]] when looking for [[aquifer]] sites for drilling [[water wells]] in Eastern [[Chad]]. Both northern [[Mali]], southern [[Libya]], southern [[Algeria]], eastern Chad were being examined in part of an ongoing project to find viable drilling as the region's nations try to find new water sources to keep up with their growing demand. In recent years, roughly 300,000 refugees have arrived from both the war-torn Sudan and ailing [[Central African Republic]], thus straining the already limited water supplies. Both [[Algeria]], Burkina Faso, [[Mauritania]], Morocco, [[Mozambique]], Niger have shown a major interest in the further development of this resource lead local industry.<ref name="circleofblue.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.circleofblue.org/waternews/2010/world/africa/x-rays-mark-the-spot-to-drill-for-water-in-chad/ |title=X-Rays Mark the Spot to Drill for Water in Chad | Circle of Blue WaterNews |publisher=Circleofblue.org |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="semp.us">{{cite web|url=http://www.semp.us/publications/biot_reader.php?BiotID=675 |title=The 37 Great Aquifer Systems of Earth: Solution to Global Drought |publisher=Semp.us |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="oss-online.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.oss-online.org/pdf/synth-sass_En.pdf |title=synth-sass_En.qxp |format=PDF |accessdate=12 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727154659/http://www.oss-online.org/pdf/synth-sass_En.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On 11 June 2010, the UN's World Food Organisation, Oxfam and MSF all warned of an impending famine in [[Mali]], Mauritania, [[Burkina Faso]], Niger and northern [[Nigeria]]. Niger's [[Diffa Region]] was of the most concern to the experts at hand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2010/jun2010/afri-j11.shtml |title=Warning of famine in West Africa |publisher=Wsws.org |date=11 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
By 13 June 2010, roughly 30% of crops failed in some of Niger's provinces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-06-13-football-fever-means-terror-famine-go-unreported |title=Football fever: Terror, famine go unreported – News – Mail & Guardian Online |publisher=Mg.co.za |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
A new heat wave hit Niger on 21 June, causing an increased area of drought in that country as well. Niger's crops failed and [[famine]] occurred. About 350,000 faced starvation and 1,200,000 were at risk of [[famine]] according to the Niger's government,<ref name="guardian2">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/21/millions-face-starvation-west-africa |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Henry |last=Foy |date=21 June 2010 |title=Millions face starvation in west Africa, warn aid agencies |accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref> while the UN said roughly 2,000,000 Chadians, 7,000,0000 Nigerians and 1,000,000 other people of the [[Sahel]] region faced starvation and 200,000 Nigerian children were malnourished.<ref name="guardian2"/>
In over-heated Chad, the temperature reached 47.6 °C (117.7 °F) on 22 June in [[Faya-Largeau]], breaking a record set in 1961 at the same location. Niger tied its highest temperature record set in 1998, on also 22 June, at 47.1 °C in [[Bilma]]. That record was broken the next day, on 23 June when Bilma hit 48.2 °C (118.8 °F). The hottest temperature recorded in Sudan was reached on 22 June, at 49.7 °C (121.3 °F) in [[Dongola]], breaking a record set in 1987. Sudan's record temperature was matched on the 23rd too.<ref name="MastersNOAA"/>
On 23 June the UN, WFP and various humanitarian agencies requested $190,700,000 million to enable them respond to the unfolding famine in Niger. The UN estimates that just under 50% of country's 7,100,000 people risked starving to death.<ref name="earthwire.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.earthwire.org/africa/?t=200342&tn=Drought |title=Africa – Recent News – Drought |publisher=EarthWire |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="un">{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201006231013.html |title=Niger: UN Relief Chief Urges Donors to Respond Quickly to Food Crisis |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=23 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 24 June the government of [[Niger]] admitted that it was suffering from a major [[famine]] and said [[aid worker]]s and NGOs were now welcome.<ref name="gefominyen.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.gefominyen.com/2010/06/world-vision-report---week-of-june-12-2010---niger-famine.html |title=GEF's Outlook: World Vision Report – Week of June 12, 2010 – Niger Famine |publisher=Gefominyen.com |date=24 June 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> The government of the [[Ivory Coast]] had reported to various NGOs that it was struggling to control [[desertification]] and imminent drought conditions in parts of its northern [[savanna]] lands.<ref name="gefominyen.com"/> [[Oxfam]] launch a £7,000,000 emergency appeal to try to help more than 800,000 of the most vulnerable people in Chad, Niger and Mali.<ref name="earthwire.org"/><ref name="un" /> 26 June saw 1,600,000 Chadians facing [[food insecurity]] in the [[Bahr el Gazel (region of Chad)|Bahr el Gazel Region]], [[Batha Region]], [[Guera Region]], [[Hadjer-Lamis]] Region, [[Lac Region]] and the [[Kanem Region]]. About 604,000 people were benefiting from its assistance as a total 60% of families became victims of the famine in varying degrees according to the UN's [[World Food Programme]] (WFP). Chad appealed to donors for increased contribution to the international famine relief operation in [[Chad]] that received US$42,100,000 of a pledged total of US$65,000,000, to enable it continue all its relief work and charitable activities until the end of the year 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/famine-affects-60-pc-of-chadian-households-2010062651778.html |accessdate=3 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703045629/http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/famine-affects-60-pc-of-chadian-households-2010062651778.html |archivedate=3 July 2010 |title=Famine affects 60 pc of Chadian households}}</ref> Cameroon also suffered from heavy desertification in the savanna regions of [[South Region (Cameroon)|South Region]], [[Centre Region (Cameroon)|Centre Region]], [[West Region (Cameroon)|West Region]], [[Northwest Region (Cameroon)|Northwest Region]] and [[Far North Region (Cameroon)|Far North Region]].<ref name="gefominyen.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrik.com/article10126.html |title=Côte d'Ivoire : l'entrave des audiences foraines menace le processus de paix – Afrik.com : l'actualité de l'Afrique noire et du Maghreb – Le quotidien panafricain |publisher=Afrik.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
===July=== [[File:2010 Sahel famine.png|thumb|right|200px| This map shows the nations hit by the 2010 Sahel African famine. Orange-tinted nations were in immediate risk of or had a famine according to the UN/ICRC or aid organisations like CAFOD. Yellow-tinted nations had heavy sandstorm, food shortages or a drought, but did not go as far as to have an actual famine itself.]]
July saw sporadic and small-scale food riots in [[Sudan]]'s [[Blue Nile]], [[Janub Darfur]], [[South Kordofan]] and [[North Kordofan]] departments.<ref>http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNADS898.pdf</ref> The [[Muslim Hands]] charity set up an appeal and sent aid to [[Niger]] and [[Mali]] in July. It was the worst Niger [[famine]] since 1984, with 3,500,000 people starving.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.muslimhands.org/en/za/appeals/niger_mali_famine/ |title=Appeals " Niger and Mali Famine |publisher=Muslim Hands |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 6 July, the [[Methodist]] Relief and Development Fund (MRDF) aid experts said that more than 1,500,000 Nigerians were at risk of famine due to a month-long heat wave that was hovering over Niger, Mali, [[Mauritania]] and [[Morocco]]. A fund of about £20,000 was distributed to the crisis-hit countries of Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso and Mauritania.<ref name="ekklesia.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/12566 |title=Methodists make appeal for famine threatened West Africa |publisher=Ekklesia |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
The [[heat wave]] that left Morocco for the [[Iberian Peninsula]] on 11 July was attributed to the regional hot air currents that depart from the [[Sahara]] desert in Northern Africa at about 1,000 meters in altitude. This facilitated a movement in the hot air towards the [[Balkans]] and the [[Ukraine]] via the [[Straits of Gibraltar]], Spain and [[Italy]].<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn">{{cite web|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90780/91345/7061886.html |title=Heat waves sizzling Northern Hemisphere – People's Daily Online |work=People's Daily |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Unusually hot weather was also reported in parts of [[Algeria]] on 11 July.<ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn"/><ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn"/><ref name="english.peopledaily.com.cn"/>
On 12 July 2010, a local goat farmer was killed and his small flock stolen by Chadian refugees in the [[South Darfur]] region of the [[Sudan]]. The UN's WFP body estimated that 2,500,000 were at risk of a famine breaking out in their part of Niger.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mohamed ElGohary, Egypt |url=http://globalvoices.org/2010/07/12/niger-the-silent-famine/ |title=Niger: The Silent Famine · Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoices.org |date=12 July 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110208112723/http://globalvoices.org/2010/07/12/niger-the-silent-famine/| archivedate= 8 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 13 July, the [[USAID]] funded [[Famine Early Warning Systems Network]] (FEWS NET), and the UN warned of a food supply shortage in northern [[Sudan]], with increasing food insecurity focused on the war torn [[Darfur]] region and other neighboring areas.<ref name="usaid">{{cite web |author=Jeff Grieco, LPA |url=http://www.usaid.gov/locations/sub-saharan_africa/sudan/ |title=USAID: The Humanitarian Situation in Sudan |publisher=Usaid.gov |accessdate=12 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017021206/http://www.usaid.gov/locations/sub-saharan_africa/sudan/ |archive-date=17 October 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The deteriorating security situation in the conflict zone was predicted to reduce both productivity and peoples' access to local agricultural well, as well as disrupting the seasonal livestock migration. USAID/OFDA provided $133,200,000 to the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization ([[FAO]]) to help remedy the crisis in the three Darfur states.<ref name="usaid" /> Concerns were also raised about the situation in Chad,<ref name="usaid" />
Three years of famine and then the recent sandstorms devastated Niger on 14 July. [[Diarrhoea]], starvation, [[gastroenteritis]], [[malnutrition]] and [[respiratory diseases]] kill and sicken many children. The new [[military junta]] appealed for international food aid and has taken serious steps to call overseas help since coming to office in February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100625-reporters-niger-famine-horizon-harvests-sahara-junta-coup-appeal-international-aid-mamadou-tandja |title=Niger: famine on the horizon? |publisher=France24 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110122113632/http://www.france24.com/en/20100625-reporters-niger-famine-horizon-harvests-sahara-junta-coup-appeal-international-aid-mamadou-tandja| archivedate= 22 January 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Sudan witnessed minor [[food riot]]ing in [[Southern Kordofan]], [[Blue Nile]], and [[Abyei]] as [[Profiteering (business)|profiteering]] locals and merchants and [[Uganda]]n exporters took advantage of the shortages in order to heavily mark up their selling prices.<ref>http://www.kline.org/campaign/East{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Sudanian savanna/index.htm</ref>
15 July saw more border conflicts between the [[Nuer people|Nuer]] and the [[Dinka people|Dinka]], further hindering aid workers in [[Southern Sudan]].<ref name="hrw.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/campaigns/sudan98/index.htm |title=Sudan: Analysis of the Current Fighting and its Relation to Famine | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=1 March 2001 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 17 July, Mohamed Béavogui, the Director of Western and Central Africa Division of the [[International Fund for Agricultural Development]] (IFAD), called for more international help for the people of the Sahel, who had a 410,000 tons of cereals and 20,000 tons of fodder deficit. He also condemned the world for not doing enough to help the Sahel, but stopped short of [[Cheminade]]'s idea of pumping water from the [[Zaire River]] into [[Lake Chad]] to reinvigorate its water supply and stop any further shrinkage.
On 24 July, the [[British Red Cross]] flew its logistics teams [[Bristol Airport]] to Niger to help the army and local officials with transportation. The relief effort has already been made possible by the response to the Red Cross's West Africa Crisis Appeal, which aims to raise £500,000. According to UN agencies, 200,000 children need treatment for malnutrition in Niger alone, as [[Oxfam]] put out an £7,000,000 appeal to cover both [[Chad]] and Niger.<ref name="alertnet.org"/><ref name="guardian2"/><ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/niger/1494739/Red-Cross-flies-team-out-on-Niger-famine-mission.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Chine |last=Mbubaegbu |title=Red Cross flies team out on Niger famine mission |date=24 July 2005 |accessdate=24 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201194255/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/niger/1494739/Red-Cross-flies-team-out-on-Niger-famine-mission.html| archivedate= 1 December 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref>
France sent unspecified food and cash aid to Mali on 25 July.<ref name="news90.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.news90.com/world/sahara-raid-may-endanger-hostage-algerian-sources/7115 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308165409/http://www.news90.com/world/sahara-raid-may-endanger-hostage-algerian-sources/7115 |archivedate=8 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
On 26 July the heat reached near-record levels over Chad and Niger,<ref name="wunderground.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1516 |title=Wunder Blog : Weather Underground |publisher=Wunderground.com |accessdate=28 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627220406/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1516 |archivedate=27 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and about 20 had reportedly died in northern Niger of dehydration on 27 July.
27 July also saw a critical situation occurring in northern Mali and Chad. About 8,000,0000 Nigerians, 1,600,000 Chadians and 500,000 Malians were on the verge of a major food shortage as the Nigerian journalist [[Tidiane Kassé]] said that by tackling the consequences rather than the causes would be a better form of long-term help for the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pambazuka.org/en/category/features/66292 |title=Food crisis in the Sahel: Real problem, false solutions |publisher=Pambazuka |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 31 July, leading economists predicted that food prices, especially wheat, would rise in Chad as [[Russia]] ends exports due to a domestic drought destroying their wheat and barley harvests.
===August===
On 1 August, [[Gadabeji]], Niger suffered 35 °C heat and drought.<ref name="niger">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/01/niger-famine-food-crisis |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Niger's markets are full yet famine shadows the dusty roads |first=Afua |last=Hirsch |date=1 August 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211173944/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/01/niger-famine-food-crisis |archivedate=11 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> On 1 August, just under 12,000,000 people in Niger (approximately 80% of the nation's entire population) faced a [[food supply]] crisis and possibly even [[famine]] conditions.<ref name="niger" /> The [[Tillabéri]] region is 30 km from the capital, [[Niamey]], on the road to the [[Sahara]]n town of [[Timbuktu]].<ref name="niger" /> Unusually severe rainfall destroyed and then rotted the farmers' crops.<ref name="niger" /> Basic food stuffs like maize, [[millet]] and [[sorghum]] were running out in West Africa's [[Sahel]]. Both [[Chad]] and northern [[Nigeria]] have a similar, but less severe problem.<ref name="alertnet.org"/><ref name="guardian2"/><ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/><ref name="niger" />
On 3 August, [[Burkina Faso]] was hit by a drought, as 4,500,000 Burkinans and 6,700,000 Nigerians faced starvation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201008031194.html |title=Niger: Famine-Struck Nation Sees Little Reason to Celebrate |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=3 August 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) said the Sudanese [[Nuer people|Nuer]]-[[Dinka]] war was hampering relief efforts and damaging agricultural output in parts of South Sudan.<ref name="hrw.org"/>
10 August saw an [[Aljazeera]] reporter say that 7,500,000 Nigerians were at risk of famine and 15,000,000 could face a famine across the Sahel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/08/2010818330966332.html |title=Niger fights prolonged drought – Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 August 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110309065622/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/08/2010818330966332.html| archivedate= 9 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
An estimated 8,000,000 people faced famine conditions in Niger on 11 August. [[Senegal]] and [[Gambia]] sent food aid to the Niger.<ref name="panapress.com">{{Cite web |url=http://www.panapress.com/Loginhome.asp?code=eng |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 August 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722150903/http://www.panapress.com/Loginhome.asp?code=eng |archive-date=22 July 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 12 August, Gianluca Ferrera, deputy director for the UN's [[World Food Programme]] in the Niger, said malnutrition and crop failures were at a record levels in 2010. Food shortages are affecting 12,000,000 people and 400,000 children face [[starvation]]. Food prices rose by about 300% since the crisis began and thus hardly any one can afford to buy the remaining food.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/editorial/markets-full,-famine-persists-380 |accessdate=17 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806125754/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/editorial/markets-full%2C-famine-persists-380 |archivedate=6 August 2010 |title=Markets full, famine persists |first1=Afua |last1=Hirsch |df= }}</ref>
14 August saw protests across [[Senegal|Sénégal]] over concerns relating to the ruling party's poor governance in the face of recent floods, storms and power cuts across the country, along with the current heavy drought in [[Senegal]]'s Sahel region.<ref>http://www.einnews.com/login.php?redir=%2Fnews.php%3Fwid%3D308875194&n=1</ref>
15 August had aid workers and their organizations warn of an imminent nationwide famine in Niger.<ref>http://www.einnews.com/login.php?redir=%2Fnews.php%3Fwid%3D308896653&n=1</ref>
On 20 August, floods which were the worst for 80 years hit the Shale region. The U.N. warned that Niger, Chad, Burkina Faso, Cameroon and northern Nigeria are also in the grip of the worst regional [[food crisis]] since 2006. In the [[savannah]] [[Kano]], Nigeria, over 2,000 families were displaced by floods and in the nearby [[Jigawa]] region, an entire village was evacuated due to heavy flooding. In [[Mauritania]], a flood damaged bridges and many homes in the mountain town of [[El Aioun, Mauritania|Aioun]]. Heavy flooding was occurring around parts of [[lake Chad]].<ref name="npr.org"/>
Most [[international aid agencies]] withdraw workers due to the regional kidnapping crisis. [[Niger]]'s government spokesman Mahamane Lawali Danda told the [[BBC]] that the pullout came as a surprise since no one had told his government Niger was on the list of dangerous 'kidnapper infested' [[pariah state]]s, along with Chad, [[Darfur]] and [[Sudan]]. Mauritania and [[Mali]] were not on the list of dangerous nations, despite several [[al-Qaeda]] lead kidnappings during 2009.<ref name="npr.org"/>
The U.N. warned of mass starvation in Niger and Chad and [[Oxfam]] said people in the region were surviving on leaves and berries picked in the wild. 8,000,000 were said to be near starvation by both organisation.<ref name="npr.org"/> The UN estimated that up to 7,800,000 Nigeriens were affected by heavy food shortages. [[Cafod]] set up a £100,000 aid programme on 21 August.<ref name="cafod.org.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.cafod.org.uk/about-us/what-we-do/emergencies/niger-drought |title=Niger: responding to drought |publisher=CAFOD |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
25 August had a French aid worker kidnapped in Chad.<ref name="afrikaspeaks.com"/> The kidnapping of foreigners along the Chad–Darfur border became more frequent in 2009. A French NGO worker was taken and then murdered on 29 October 2009,<ref name="sudaneseonline.com"/> and an unidentified Red Cross worker was captured on 10 November 2009.<ref name="earthtimes.org"/> Many NGOs and charities had started to restrict the areas covered by their aid work in Niger, Chad and Sudan, due to the ever-present risk of [[bandit]]s and [[kidnap]]ers.
On 28 August, charities and NGOs put out food shortage alerts for Niger.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/alex-haxton-the-next-disaster-has-already-begun-2064722.html |location=London |work=The Independent |title=The next disaster has already begun |date=29 August 2010| accessdate=24 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> Heavy rain falls on the border of the [[Central African Republic|CAR]] and the Chad.
31 August saw 7,900,000 of Niger's 15,300,000 people in immediate risk of starvation and [[Gordon Brown]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] making plans for a $100,000 charity speech on the development of irrigation and water schemes to increase cultivable land the Niger and the Chad.<ref name="independent.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/brown-returns-to-politics-with-a-plea-for-faminestricken-niger-2066143.html |location=London |work=The Independent |first=Martin |last=Hickman |title=Brown returns to politics with a plea for famine-stricken Niger | date=31 August 2010| accessdate=24 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> He was quoted to have said in the interview that:
<blockquote>But, today, where there is suffering without hope, we can prevent children dying painful, avoidable deaths<ref name="independent.co.uk"/></blockquote>
On 31 August Sudan's army reported that 3 Russian helicopter crew members had been abducted by gunmen in Nyala, capital of South Darfur, just hours after [[Samaritan's Purse]] aid worker [[Flavia Wagner]] who had been kidnapped 18 May was set free.<ref name="english.sina.com"/><ref name="english.sina.com"/> She was taken from the [[South Darfur]]ian village of [[Abu Ajura]], along with two Sudanese colleagues who were also freed after a week.<ref name="english.sina.com"/><ref name="english.sina.com"/> The governor of South Darfur, [[Abdel Hamid Kasha]], Sudan [[foreign ministry]] spokesman [[Moawiya Osman]] and Samaritan's Purse's leader [[Franklin Graham]], and the Russian ambassador to Chad welcomed Flavia's release, but condemned the [[kidnap]] of the three Russians and that of two [[Jordan]]ian [[UNAMID]] police advisers in Darfur, on the 14th.<ref name="english.sina.com"/> Another Russian [[helicopter]] pilot was taken prisoner for four days after landing in [[South Darfur]] to take rebels' spokesmen to Chad for alleged peace talks.<ref name="english.sina.com"/>
===September=== On 1 September, aid agencies and NGOs called for aid to be given to Niger as 7,000,000 faced starvation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.periscopepost.com/2010/09/niger-dying-in-silence/ |title=Niger dying in silence |publisher=The Periscope Post |date=24 August 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101229012353/http://www.periscopepost.com/2010/09/niger-dying-in-silence/| archivedate= 29 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
4 September had [[Cholera]] outbreaks kill 41 in Chad and one in Nigeria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dowell-netherlands.com/2010/09/cholera-kills-41-in-chad.html |title=Cholera kills 41 in Chad | Chen Qi-The World of Micro-Organism |publisher=Dowell-netherlands.com |date=4 September 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
8 September saw a [[the PRC|Chinese]] [[CGC Overseas Construction Co. Ltd.]] oil worker kidnapped in [[Bahai]] inside [[Chad]] and took him to [[Sharq al-Teyna]], in [[Sudan]]'s [[Darfur]] region.<ref name="peopledaily1"/><ref name="alertnet2"/><ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite news|last=Mazen |first=Maram |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-15/sudanese-chadian-forces-search-for-kidnapped-chinese-worker-along-border.html |title=Sudanese, Chadian Forces Search for Kidnapped Chinese Worker Along Border |publisher=Bloomberg |date=15 September 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="alertnet3"/><ref name="news1"/>
On 13 September the [[Prem Rawat Foundation]] gave $30,000 loan to pay for [[Niger]] to buy food aid for children of its nomadic tribal groups.<ref name="prnewswire.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-prem-rawat-foundation-helps-children-of-nomadic-tribes-in-niger-102772649.html |title=The Prem Rawat Foundation Helps Children of Nomadic Tribes in Niger – LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 /PRNewswire-USNewswire/ |location=Africa, California |publisher=Prnewswire.com |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>
On 14 September heavy rainfall in central and southern Chad raised hopes that the major drought in Africa's Sahel region would be over by early 2011.<ref name="af.reuters.com">{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE68D0NH20100914 |work=Reuters |title=Famine threat in Africa's Sahel eases – for now |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=24 December 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110102145348/https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE68D0NH20100914 |archivedate=2 January 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="news3">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/Famine-threat-in-Sahel-eases-20100914 |title=Famine threat in Sahel eases : News24: Africa: News |publisher=News24 |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> 10,000,000 were near to starvation in the [[Sahel]]. The UN's WFP had estimated that Chad needs about 100,000 metric tonnes of food aid, but had only received 70,000 metric tonnes so far. Most of the Chadian need to sell more cereal crops to make enough money to repay their huge [[debts]]. farmers According to [[Jean Francois Caremel]] of the [[Action Against Hunger]] charity branch in Chad.<ref name="af.reuters.com"/><ref name="news3"/> As both Chad and Niger faced an improving situation due to heavy rain fall over these countries, but a major famine was still unfolding in other countries of West Africa's dry Sahelian region<ref name="af.reuters.com"/>
15 September had Sudanese and Chadian forces jointly searching for both the Chinese [[oil industry]] engineer taken on the 8th and a Chinese [[aid worker]] who was kidnapped from the same town on the morning of the 15th. Both the Chinese [[ambassador]] to Chad, the Chadian government and the [[Solidarity Action for Peace and Development]] NGO condemned the [[kidnapping]]s.<ref name="peopledaily1"/><ref name="alertnet2"/><ref name="bloomberg.com"/><ref name="alertnet3"/> <ref name="news1"/><ref name="africanews.com"/> The Chinese hostage was released in the [[Dafur]] on the 17th.<ref name="news.yahoo.com"/>
18 and 19 September In [[Hadejia]], Nigeria, The flood victims sleep wherever they can, the men search for dry spots on the roads while women and children keep piling into their houses still standing as huge number of displaced people have returned to flood-hit villages in Northern Nigeria. Over two million people were affected by the flood waters and more than 50,000 families are still wandering homeless. Residential areas of the [[Kararar Rima village]] was also destroyed in the flood. Most of the houses were made of clay, so they easy [[Dissolution (chemistry)|dissolved]] in the flood water.<ref name="google.com">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iguvcTEOiu7FW6ptKz_UKMeKNOgQ?docId=CNG.df9e6a188a034ac23300ab0760b91861.8f1 AFP: Flood victims sleep by roadsides in northern Nigeria]</ref> As the rains fell the end of the pending famine looked close.
===October=== {{Main|2010 Nigerien floods}}
The famine was finally relieved, as floods hit [[Ghana]], Niger, [[Nigeria]] and [[Benin]] in October 2010.<ref name="Benin 2"/> [[Cotonou]]’s residents in [[Benin]] had to board canoes, on the 9th due to severe flooding. According to the UN, 680,000 people were homeless while more than 300,000 acres of crops had been destroyed and 81,000 livestock killed.<ref name="Benin 2">{{cite web|url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39967007/ns/weather|title= 39967007/ns; |publisher= msnbc.msn.com |accessdate=15 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101107075630/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39967007/ns/weather| archivedate= 7 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Flooding began in mid-September when heavy rains caused the [[Niger River]] in Benin's north to overflow and break its banks. Rainfall continued across the country.<ref name="Benin 2"/> Heavy rains caused the collapse of an already damaged dam in [[Ghana]] and displaced more than 700,000 people.<ref name="Benin 2"/>
